text: well let's turn to this story now the
Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi he's
calling for calm following days of
sectarian violence between Hindus and
Muslims that has killed at least 27
people the unrest has been centered
around Muslim majority neighborhoods
there in the northeast off tally and
there are reports that Muslim homes and
shops are being deliberately targeted
the BBC's Regina party in Athens sent us
this report fear as tensions remain high
in Delhi the national capital a
battleground violent clashes between
Hindus and Muslims have rocked the city
for days entire neighbourhoods ripped
apart as mobs roam the streets the riots
have been centered in the northeast of
the city in largely Muslim neighborhoods
this mosque was set alight the charred
remains lay scattered the death tolls
rising both Muslims and Hindus
casualties of these clashes thanks very
much to Rajini well there are some truly
harrowing stories coming out off the
violence this is one this is about an 85
year old woman who was burned to death
in her home on Tuesday now remember this
all started over a controversial
citizenship law that grants amnesty to
non Muslim immigrants from neighboring
countries but not to Muslims mr. Modi
whose Hindu nationalist party has been
accused of fueling violence something it
denies has broken his three-day silence
on the issue he has tweeted let's take a
look he says peace and harmony are
central to our ethos I appealed to my
sisters and brothers of Delhi to
maintain peace and Brotherhood at all
times it's important that there is calm
and normalcy restored at the earliest
amid criticism about the government's
lack of response officials are have on
Wednesday been making extra efforts to
show that they're taking the issue
seriously let's take a look here this is
India's national security adviser who's
been visiting the worst affected areas
to try and reassure people and here's
what you had to say about how the
situation is being handled all the
communities are cooperating there is no
need for fear we have to put enough
security forces the police is doing its
job with complete diligence what
questions are being asked about
taking the police so long to begin
restoring peace to the city among them
is one journalist who's been describing
to the BBC what she faced in one of the
neighborhoods at the center of the
violence there was absolutely no police
in the entire area
there were mobs at different places
there were multiple mobs
holding lattes sticks and they were
sporting a tikka a Safran tikka on their
heads and you know they were calling for
openly calling for an extermination of
Muslims you know and I when there as a
journalist and I was really really
scared because first of all they were
not receptive of journalists and second
of all the thing was that I was a Muslim
myself what comparisons have been drawn
between the violent scenes we've been
seeing on the alleys streets and also
the country's worst ever instances of
sectarian violence let's get more of a
sense how Muslims and Hindus are feeling
here's the BBC's yoghurts LMI we've
spoken to people from both communities
Muslims have told us they feel extremely
scared they they accused the police of
abetting with the Hindus to beat them
vandalize their homes what the Hindus
have told us is that the Muslims were
shooting at them and throwing stones at
them we've also been to a small Hospital
in the area where doctors said they
couldn't cope but even ambulances
couldn't make it through from here to
take patients who were grievously
injured to bigger and better hospitals
and this area even today remains tense
